This is a new thread to discuss the specific question of whether 1516 x=y2⋄(x⋄(x⋄y))x = y^2 \diamond (x \diamond (x \diamond y))x=y2⋄(x⋄(x⋄y)) implies 255 x=x4x = x^4x=x4, where we recursively define xn+1=xn⋄x=Rxnxx^{n+1} = x^n \diamond x = R_x^n xxn+1=xn⋄x=Rxn​x. This, and its dual, would resolve two open implications. It has been discussed extensively in a previous thread; I now summarize some progress here.

Immunities:

  • (T) Implication is true for translation-invariant models (even noncommutative ones).
  • (L) Implication is true for linear models (even noncommutative ones).
  • (F) Implication is true for finite models.
  • (C) Implication is true for commutative models.
  • Implication is true if squaring is surjective.
  • Implication is true if one has "flip-injectivity": a ◇ b = c ◇ d implies b ◇ a = d ◇ c.

Examples:

  • The smallest non-trivial finite magma is of order 5. (In view of comments:) This is the law x⋄y=3x+3yx \diamond y = 3x + 3yx⋄y=3x+3y on Z/5Z{\mathbb Z}/5{\mathbb Z}Z/5Z. In particular x2=xx^2 = xx2=x in this case. This is also a translation-invariant, commutative model.
  • (Added in view of comments below:) Another linear model is x⋄y=4x+yx \diamond y = 4x + yx⋄y=4x+y on Z/7Z{\mathbb Z}/7{\mathbb Z}Z/7Z. In this model, x2=5xx^2 = 5xx2=5x, x3=0x^3 = 0x3=0, and x4=xx^4 = xx4=x, and then xnx^nxn repeats with period 3.

Some known identities/properties for 1516 magmas:

  • x2=Lx23x=Lx22(x3)x^2 = L_{x^2}^3 x = L_{x^2}^2(x^3)x2=Lx23​x=Lx22​(x3)
  • Lx2L_{x^2}Lx2​ is surjective
  • (x3)2=(x2)3(x^3)^2 = (x^2)^3(x3)2=(x2)3
  • x2=(x3)2⋄x2=(x2)4x^2 = (x^3)^2 \diamond x^2 = (x^2)^4x2=(x3)2⋄x2=(x2)4. That is to say, 255 is true for square numbers.

1516 does not seem to obviously imply

  • x=xnx = x^nx=xn for n=7,10, 13,16,19,22n = 7, 10,  13, 16, 19, 22n=7,10, 13,16,19,22.
  • x=Lx3(x3)x = L_x^3(x^3)x=Lx3​(x3)

Some rules from the greedy ruleset:

  • If x2=xx^2 = xx2=x and x⋄y=xx \diamond y = xx⋄y=x then y2=xy^2 = xy2=x
  • If x⋄y=y⋄x=xx \diamond y = y \diamond x = xx⋄y=y⋄x=x then x2=xx^2 = xx2=x
  • If x⋄y=y⋄y=xx \diamond y = y \diamond y = xx⋄y=y⋄y=x then x2=xx^2 = xx2=x
Do we have a tptp for this one?

The smallest non-trivial magma mentioned above is linear. I thought it might be useful to describe all linear maps

x⋄y=ax+by+cx\diamond y = ax+by+cx⋄y=ax+by+c

satisfying 1516.

The carrier ring must be commutative, and a reduction system is given by

ba↦abba\mapsto abba↦ab

ab2↦−ab+1ab^2\mapsto -ab+1ab2↦−ab+1

b3↦−ab−a2 b^3\mapsto -ab-a^2b3↦−ab−a2

a2b↦−a3−ab−b+1a^2b\mapsto -a^3-ab-b+1a2b↦−a3−ab−b+1

a4↦2a3+b2+b+2a−1a^4\mapsto 2a^3+b^2+b+2a-1a4↦2a3+b2+b+2a−1

b2c↦−bc−ac−cb^2c\mapsto -bc-ac-cb2c↦−bc−ac−c

a2c↦−ac−ca^2c\mapsto -ac-ca2c↦−ac−c

Not the simplest system in the world.

The 5-element magma corresponds to the ring Z/5Z\mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z}Z/5Z taking a=b=3,c=0a=b=3, c=0a=b=3,c=0.

The model x⋄y=3x+3yx \diamond y = 3x + 3yx⋄y=3x+3y on Z/5Z{\mathbb Z}/5{\mathbb Z}Z/5Z is idempotent, x2=xx^2 = xx2=x. Is there a slightly larger model which isn't idempotent? I don't see a+b=1a+b=1a+b=1 listed among your laws, so I suspect the answer is "yes".
Running a search in Z/pZ\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}Z/pZ for small primes, there are lots of examples. The smallest where the idempotent law fails is when p=7,a=4,b=1p=7, a=4, b=1p=7,a=4,b=1.

That law x⋄y=4x+yx \diamond y= 4x + yx⋄y=4x+y on Z/7Z{\mathbb Z}/7{\mathbb Z}Z/7Z might serve as a good test model as a first approximation of what rules might and might not be consequences of 1516. For instance here we have x2=5xx^2 = 5xx2=5x, x3=0x^3 = 0x3=0, x4=xx^4 = xx4=x, and xnx^nxn just repeats periodically mod 3. Which is of course consistent with your request to investigate x=xnx = x^nx=xn for various n=1 mod 3 n = 1 \hbox{ mod } 3n=1 mod 3.
Just checked that the relations force all linear maps to satisfy x4=xx^4=xx4=x.
I think you had previously confirmed that this implication was immune to linear models (even noncommutative ones), but it doesn't hurt to double check.
Oh yeah, I forgot for a moment that the target was x4=xx^4=xx4=x. Good to have double-checked it!

For a system with many immunities, one strategy that I haven't seen mentioned could be a LORC (linear on residue classes) function. There's a couple ways to think of it, one would be operations of the form "if x is even and y is odd [foo], else if x is odd [bar], else [baz]" and so on, but generalized to arbitrary mod k. Another way to look at it is that the magma on (Fin k)×ℤ -- or some other ring, doesn't have to be ℤ -- with a sort of semidirect product structure. The map (x,y) -> x gives a homomorphism to a k-element magma, and for all i and j, the map fun x y => ((i,x) ⋄ (j,y)).2 is linear.

We could try this (mostly by hand I guess) by trying successively larger k, taking a k-element magma that obeys the law, and then trying to fill in the k^2 linear functions. I think a few other infinite examples people used to solve hard nonimplications follow this form with k=2, which is why I have some hope it could work further
Although, in this case, that could get very messy fast. Hmm. The smallest nontrivial example is on 5 elements, which means you need 25 linear functions, or to solve for some 75 variables.
Well, I plunk out the system of equations and see if there's an obvious thing to do. Maybe there's even lots of solutions! :)
It's worth a shot, though the immunity that this problem has to constructions in which squaring is surjective gives me some pause.

Do the finite magmas satisfying 1516 always have a surjective square map? The ones listed above all do

Assuming so, that means that (since the homomorphism to Fin k will lead to a surjective square map), if we don't want a LORC construction to have a surjective square, we need at least one of the ax+by+c maps to have gcd(a,b) != 1. And that's sufficient then for having it not be a surjective squaring map

Well, the k=5 case doesn't work at least (with the ring as Z). Since it's idempotent, there's a closed submagma on (1,x), and indeed for every (i,x). Since by construction that's a linear model, it has to obey the equations people discussed earlier. I derived them as a * (b^2-b) = 1 together with either 1-b+2b^2-2b^3+b^4 = 0 or (c = 0 and -1-b+b^3 = 0). Solving these over ℂ, we find that there are no integer solutions. (There are solutions over ℂ, in fact over the algebraic integers, but then the squaring map on this submagma is surjective.) Since the squaring map on these submagmas is surjective, it's also true of the whole magma, so it can't be a counterexample.

All finite 1516 models have surjective squaring map. Proof So this is indeed a significant obstacle to LORC constructions, since they will likely have finite models thanks to the Lefschetz principle (unless one works with a noncommutative LORC).
This massive amount of immunity is annoying!

I see. Furthermore I found that it doesn't work with the p=7 case above, because just having a _single_ idempotent element actually makes the argument above fall through. In the p=7 case, 0^2 = 0, and so the submagma induced there again needs some a/b/c to work, and there are no rational solutions. So there's no LORC over Z sitting above the p=7 magma, or above any finite magma with at least one idempotent element.

And then -- I didn't quite the follow the Lefschetz part, it's not my area, but I think this is the idea? -- we could say, okay, instead of taking the ring to be Z, we could take (say) the algebraic integers, where we do have a solution for the idempotent elements. And we could then still have a map like x⋄y = 2x+4y for one of the other parts, something that isn't surjective on the algebraic integers. So in that way we could get a LORC that doesn't have a surjective squaring map. But if we had that, we could just extend it to operating on C instead of the algebraic integers, and now squaring is surjective, so it will necessarily obey 255.

I guess I'm using the Lefschetz principle in a slightly nonstandard form, namely that any first-order statement that is true over a characteristic 0 algebraically closed field such as C, is also true in (algebraically closed) fields of sufficiently large finite characteristic p, and hence also in certain finite fields of large characteristic; this basically follows by combining the usual form of the Lefschetz principle with the compactness theorem in logic. There is a nice article of Serre describing this technique, for instance to prove the Ax-Grothendieck theorem (which is relevant here). I think this method shows that any polynomial or PORC type construction in any field will necessarily induce a similar construction in a finite field, which we know already to be impossible.

Alright, that makes sense now, thanks! (It's been a while since I had occasion to think about the Ax-Grothendieck theorem, but it's a happy memory; such a fun result.) So, this also rules out PORC type constructions over any commutative ring of characteristic 0, since they could always be extended to the field of fractions. In particular, nothing over Z. Would have to look at something noncommutative, or with positive characteristic.

I'm thinking that a NORC (nonlinear over residue classes, aka an extension of a finite model) has a chance (it's basically the same strategy @Bernhard Reinke outlined over on the 1323 thread). Taking the Z/5Z{\mathbb Z}/5{\mathbb Z}Z/5Z model is problematic due to squaring being idempotent there, so let's take the Z/7Z{\mathbb Z}/7{\mathbb Z}Z/7Z model instead. So our carrier is now of the form G×Z/7ZG \times {\mathbb Z}/7{\mathbb Z}G×Z/7Z with a magma operation of the form
(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(x⋄a,by,4a+b) (x, a) \diamond (y,b) = (x \diamond_{a,b} y, 4a+b)(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(x⋄a,b​y,4a+b)
where we have a frightening-looking 49 separate magma operations ⋄a,b:G×G→G \diamond_{a,b}: G \times G \to G⋄a,b​:G×G→G. However, we can take advantage of dilation symmetry to make the projective ansatz ⋄ka,kb=⋄a,b\diamond_{ka, kb} = \diamond_{a,b}⋄ka,kb​=⋄a,b​ for all invertible kkk, which cuts us down to "just" 1 + 48/6 = 9 magma operations. The law 1516 can now be computed to take the form
(y⋄b,by)⋄5b,a+b(x⋄a,4a+b(x⋄a,by))=x (y \diamond_{b,b} y) \diamond_{5b, a+b} (x \diamond_{a,4a+b} (x \diamond_{a,b} y)) = x(y⋄b,b​y)⋄5b,a+b​(x⋄a,4a+b​(x⋄a,b​y))=x
for all a,b,x,ya,b,x,ya,b,x,y. This is 49 different magma-type laws, but with the projective ansatz we cut back to 9. Firstly there is the a=b=0 case, which is just saying that ⋄0,0\diamond_{0,0}⋄0,0​ obeys 1516. Then we have the b=0,a=1b=0, a=1b=0,a=1 case, which is
(y⋄0,0y)⋄0,1(x⋄1,4(x⋄1,1y))=x;(1) (y \diamond_{0,0} y) \diamond_{0, 1} (x \diamond_{1,4} (x \diamond_{1,1} y)) = x; \quad (1)(y⋄0,0​y)⋄0,1​(x⋄1,4​(x⋄1,1​y))=x;(1)
the b=1,a=0b=1, a=0b=1,a=0 case, which is
(y⋄1,1y)⋄1,3(x⋄0,1(x⋄0,1y))=x(2) (y \diamond_{1,1} y) \diamond_{1, 3} (x \diamond_{0,1} (x \diamond_{0,1} y)) = x \quad (2) (y⋄1,1​y)⋄1,3​(x⋄0,1​(x⋄0,1​y))=x(2)
and then six more cases with a=1a=1a=1 and bbb non-zero, which are
(y⋄1,1y)⋄1,(b+1)/5b(x⋄1,b+4(x⋄1,by))=x.(3) (y \diamond_{1,1} y) \diamond_{1, (b+1)/5b} (x \diamond_{1,b+4} (x \diamond_{1,b} y)) = x. \quad (3)(y⋄1,1​y)⋄1,(b+1)/5b​(x⋄1,b+4​(x⋄1,b​y))=x.(3)
Bearing in mind that squaring shouldn't be surjective, it is tempting to make y⋄1,1yy \diamond_{1,1} yy⋄1,1​y equal to a constant 0 to simplify the latter two rules. (We have no examples of 1516 magmas with squaring not surjective right now, so we can't easily make y⋄0,0yy \diamond_{0,0} yy⋄0,0​y non-surjective.) The hope is now that the various magma operations here are sufficiently "decoupled" from each other that it becomes easier to construct counterexamples.

Unfortunately, we can't simultaneously make squaring in ⋄0,0\diamond_{0,0}⋄0,0​ surjective while setting squaring in ⋄1,1\diamond_{1,1}⋄1,1​ equal to a constant 000. The former hypothesis together with (1) makes all the left multiplication operators Ly0,1L_y^{0,1}Ly0,1​ surjective, where Lya,bL_y^{a,b}Lya,b​ denotes left-multiplication x↦y⋄a,byx \mapsto y \diamond_{a,b} yx↦y⋄a,b​y. On the other hand the latter hypothesis and (2) makes L01,3L^{1,3}_0L01,3​ surjective, hence L01,3(Lx0,1)2L^{1,3}_0 (L^{0,1}_x)^2L01,3​(Lx0,1​)2 is surjective, but from (2) and the above hypothesis we know that this map is also constant, a contradiction.

One can still hope that a greedy construction works here, but it doesn't look appetizing; one can wait to see if the simpler situation in 1323 falls to this approach first.

A difference to the situation in 1323 is that 255 is a law in only one variable, while for 1323 we want to refute a law in two variables. Part of my assumptions in 1323 is that one-generated submagmas are as simple as possible, namely isomorphic to the finite magma that we are extending over. We of course cannot make this assumption here.

On the other hand, if there is a counterexample, there should be a one-generated counterexample. So I am curious what happens in the following case: z should be our generator and impose z4≠z z^4 \neq zz4=z, what kind of inequalities in the terms in z can we deduce? For example we get z2≠z z^2 \neq z z2=z. Are there any other easy ones?

In semigroups and rings, elements satisfying the periodic identity xn=xn+kx^n=x^{n+k}xn=xn+k, for some integers n,k≥1n,k\geq 1n,k≥1 are well-studied. If we take nnn to be the smallest such integer it is called the index, and then the smallest such kkk is called the period. Moreover, then xj=xj+ix^j=x^{j+i}xj=xj+i if and only if j≥nj\geq nj≥n and k∣ik\mid ik∣i.

It seems that these types of facts carry over to the magma setting, using left-parenthesized powers, by the same arguments. Since we are trying to avoid x=x4x=x^4x=x4, it is interesting to ask which of its consequences might hold.

Also, it seems that tripling of multiplication is common when working with 1516. So I'm wondering whether or not 1516 implies x10=x19x^{10}=x^{19}x10=x19. (This should cover the other identities I was asking about earlier.)
Checked these in Vampire, and it timed out.

Pace Nielsen ha dicho:

Checked these in Vampire, and it timed out.

imagen.png

Below, for ease of notation, I'm going to suppress the diamond operation by using concatenation and parentheses. Also, I take x1:=xx^1:=xx1:=x and xn+1:=xnxx^{n+1}:=x^nxxn+1:=xnx as usual.

I'm wondering if some of the techniques that helped solve 854 might apply to 1516, in the following sense. Looking at the equation explorer, we see that 1516 does not imply any other equation (below 4684) except 1426 (coming from taking y=x) and the trivial equation 1. Thus, one might a priori hope that a reduced form could be found by blindly applying the 1516 reduction rule, taking anything looking like y^2(x(xy)) to x, repeatedly in subwords.

However, after a little computation, we see that this isn't the case. For instance, taking y=z,x=z2y=z, x=z^2y=z,x=z2 in 1516 yields

z2(z2z3)=z2z^2(z^2z^3)=z^2z2(z2z3)=z2

and so (as mentioned at the very beginning of this thread) we get a new relation

(z3)2z2=(z3)2(z2(z2z3))=z2.(z^3)^2z^2 = (z^3)^2(z^2(z^2z^3))=z^2.(z3)2z2=(z3)2(z2(z2z3))=z2.

Thus, even though z2z^2z2 and (z3)2z2(z^3)^2z^2(z3)2z2 are both reduced under "blind" applications of 1516, they are nonetheless equivalent.

So we add this new reduction rule to our list of rules, and try again. If I understand correctly (someone please correct me if I'm wrong), someone performed this sort of computation and the process of finding a normal form does not appear to converge to a simple finite set of rules. However, the hope is that by studying enough of the forced new rules, we might be able to glean a new (non-forced) principle that would let us find a reduced form for magmas "close" to 1516.

If someone has access to the program that searched for a normal form, could it be modified to spit out the first 10 (say) new reduction rules that are forced in 1516 magmas? I'm hopeful that we can notice a pattern. [Really, we only need to consider 1-generated 1516 magmas, since we are trying to refute a 1-variable law.]

Here are the first few new reduction relations I found in addition to the ones above.

x2=(y(yx))2(x2y)x^2 = (y(yx))^2(x^2y)x2=(y(yx))2(x2y)

y2=((x(xy))((x(xy))y))2xy^2=((x(xy))((x(xy))y))^2xy2=((x(xy))((x(xy))y))2x

Okay, I found something that is puzzling to me, but Vampire seems to confirm (if I entered it correctly).

Assuming 1516, if x=y⋄zx=y\diamond zx=y⋄z, then y=(z⋄z)⋄(y⋄x)y=(z\diamond z)\diamond (y\diamond x)y=(z⋄z)⋄(y⋄x).
I think this is just a relabeling of 1516.
You are right.

Does this give us an infinite sequence of reductions? Starting from a=b2(a(ab))a=b^2(a(ab))a=b2(a(ab)), we then get (taking x=a,y=b2,z=a(ab)x=a,y=b^2,z=a(ab)x=a,y=b2,z=a(ab) ) the new reduction b2=(a(ab))2(b2a)b^2=(a(ab))^2(b^2a)b2=(a(ab))2(b2a), which in turn gives us the new rule (a(ab))2=(b2a)2[(a(ab))2b2](a(ab))^2 =(b^2a)^2[(a(ab))^2b^2](a(ab))2=(b2a)2[(a(ab))2b2], etc... Not sure if this stabilizes, or gives lots of independent reductions.

We have x=yz⇒y=(z2)(yx)x=yz \Rightarrow y=(z^2)(yx)x=yz⇒y=(z2)(yx). Vampire times out on the converse, so it seems a safe bet that it just doesn't hold. OTOH, if we impose the converse implication anyway, Vampire continues to time out on Eq255. So, to avoid an explosion of new reduction rules, it might be helpful to add the assumption

y=(z2)(yx)⇒x=yz.y=(z^2)(yx) \Rightarrow x=yz.y=(z2)(yx)⇒x=yz.
This comes close to imposing the requirement that squaring is injective. If we impose that as well, does that trivialize the problem?

Related to this, one could explore whether left or right cancellability has any impact on the problem. For instance, left cancellability implies injective squaring: if y2=z2y^2=z^2y2=z2 then Ly2Lx2y=Ly2Lx2zL_{y^2} L_x^2 y = L_{y^2} L_x^2 zLy2​Lx2​y=Ly2​Lx2​z, hence y=zy=zy=z if left multiplication is injective.

Vampire times out when trying to prove Eq255 (after 999s), assuming Eq1516 + left-cancellativity + the converse implication I mentioned above. So probably we can assume left-cancellativity as well. (Eq1516 + right-cancellativity does give Eq255.)

By the way, left cancellability also implies the converse implication you stated anyway, since if y=(z2)(yx)y = (z^2)(yx)y=(z2)(yx) then (z2)(yx)=(z2)(y(yz))(z^2)(yx) = (z^2)(y(yz))(z2)(yx)=(z2)(y(yz)) and hence x=yzx = yzx=yz by left cancellability.

We already knew that Lx2L_{x^2}Lx2​ was surjective, so now with left cancellability these maps are now invertible. So for instance x3=Lx2−2(x2)x^3 = L_{x^2}^{-2}(x^2)x3=Lx2−2​(x2) and x=Lx2−3(x2)x = L_{x^2}^{-3}( x^2)x=Lx2−3​(x2). From 1516 the inverse is in fact explicitly given as Lx2−1y=y(yx)L_{x^2}^{-1} y = y(yx)Lx2−1​y=y(yx).

It is possible that left-cancellability is in fact true in the free group M1516M_{1516}M1516​, which could lead to further useful properties on that group. Do we know of any consequence of 1516 of the form w⋄w′≡w⋄w′′w \diamond w' \equiv w \diamond w''w⋄w′≡w⋄w′′ for some words w,w′,w′′w,w',w''w,w′,w′′ with w′≢w′′w' \not\equiv w''w′≡w′′?

One possible consequence of left-cancellability, in addition to injectivity of the squaring map, is a unique factorization claim w1⋄w2≡w3⋄w4  ⟹  w1≡w3∧w2≡w4w_1 \diamond w_2 \equiv w_3 \diamond w_4 \implies w_1 \equiv w_3 \wedge w_2 \equiv w_4w1​⋄w2​≡w3​⋄w4​⟹w1​≡w3​∧w2​≡w4​ when w1,w3w_1,w_3w1​,w3​ are not equivalent to squares.
I suppose that's not too surprising given the known finite linear models.

Most of the linear models seem to be left-cancellative as well.

Under the working hypothesis that the free group is left-cancellative, this should imply that squaring is injective, and then I think the only way to rewrite a non-square xxx into an equivalent form x′x'x′ is either by showing their components agree, xL=xL′x_L = x'_LxL​=xL′​, xR=xR′x_R = x'_RxR​=xR′​ (i.e., one is in the "unique factorization scenario"), or else if one can first show that x(xy)x(xy)x(xy) is rewritable into x′(x′y)x'(x'y)x′(x′y) for some yyy. If one can safely conjecture that x(xy)x(xy)x(xy) is never a square when xxx is not a square then there is a chance of iterating this and actually establishing some of these conjectures by some sort of induction argument.

[EDIT: actually this probably doesn't work unless one assumes that both xxx and its left component xLx_LxL​ are non-squares, but then in the absence of unique factorization, "left component" might not be well defined. Ugh, maybe the free magma here is actually quite gross...]

My experience with the 854 free group suggests that once has a near-complete list of properties (such as unique factorization or left cancellability) that you (correctly) conjecture the free magma to satisfy, you can prove them all in a giant induction, but if you only have a partial list of these properties, you can't prove anything (sort of like how if you only have a portion of a working greedy ruleset, one cannot draw any useful conclusions, other than perhaps a clue as to what the next addition to the ruleset needs to be).
(deleted)

OK, I think here is what one can correctly say about the free magma by tracing through all possible rewrite options: if x=xL⋄xRx = x_L \diamond x_Rx=xL​⋄xR​ and x′=xL′⋄xR′x' = x'_L \diamond x'_Rx′=xL′​⋄xR′​ are words with xLx_LxL​ not equivalent to a square, and xL′x'_LxL′​ not equivalent to a square, then in order to prove x≡x′x \equiv x'x≡x′, one must either first prove xL≡xL′x_L \equiv x'_LxL​≡xL′​ and xR≡xR′x_R \equiv x'_RxR​≡xR′​, or else one must first prove x⋄(x⋄y)≡x′⋄(x′⋄y′) x \diamond (x \diamond y) \equiv x' \diamond (x' \diamond y')x⋄(x⋄y)≡x′⋄(x′⋄y′) for some y,y′y,y'y,y′ with y⋄y≡y′⋄y′y \diamond y \equiv y' \diamond y'y⋄y≡y′⋄y′.

Basically, there are three different type of rewrites one can apply to a word w=wL⋄wRw = w_L \diamond w_Rw=wL​⋄wR​. Firstly, one can rewrite wLw_LwL​ into something equivalent, or wRw_RwR​ into something equivalent; let me call these "low level rewrites". Or one can do a "top level expansion", replacing www with y2⋄(w⋄(w⋄y))y^2 \diamond (w \diamond (w \diamond y))y2⋄(w⋄(w⋄y)) for some yyy. Or, one can do a "top level reduction", if www happens to be of the form y2⋄(w′⋄(w′⋄y))y^2 \diamond (w' \diamond (w' \diamond y))y2⋄(w′⋄(w′⋄y)) in which case it can be reduced to w′w'w′. So every element www of MMM is either a generator, or is uniquely factorable into the form SsCc(wL∗wR)S^s C^c (w_L * w_R)SsCc(wL​∗wR​) for some natural numbers s,cs,cs,c and some smaller words wL,wR∈Mw_L, w_R \in MwL​,wR​∈M. One can think of elements of MMM as decorated trees in which the leaf nodes are generators and the branching nodes are decorated by pairs (s,c)(s,c)(s,c) of natural numbers. For instance if x,yx,yx,y are generators then SC((Sx∗Cy)∗(y∗S2x))SC( (Sx * Cy) * (y * S^2x))SC((Sx∗Cy)∗(y∗S2x)) would be a typical word in MMM. So MMM is a magma with two commuting operations S,CS,CS,C, but I stress that these operations are not homomorphisms: S(w1∗w2)≠Sw1∗Sw2S(w_1 * w_2) \neq Sw_1 * Sw_2S(w1​∗w2​)=Sw1​∗Sw2​ for instance.

Intuitively, reducible triples encode all the identities of the form x⋄(yL⋄yR)=yLx \diamond (y_L \diamond y_R) = y_Lx⋄(yL​⋄yR​)=yL​ with yL⋄yRy_L \diamond y_RyL​⋄yR​ irreducible that are forced by 854, and the sporadic triples encode all the other identities. My hope is that most pairs are irreducible, a few triples are reducible, and a very small number of triples are sporadic.

The hard part is to figure out all the definitions of the terms in quotes. The definition of irreducibility is clear: (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) is irreducible if yyy is not of the form y=yL∗yRy = y_L * y_Ry=yL​∗yR​ for some reducible triple (x,yL,yR)(x,y_L,y_R)(x,yL​,yR​), and there is no sporadic triple of the form (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z).                 or (A,A) if element is A

x * y = head(y) if head(x) = tail(x) and head(y) = head(tail(y)) and head(x) = tail(tail(y))

Hmm... it's not the most constructive, but here is an attempt at a finite algorithm defining an eqn1516 magma that violates eqn255.

Represent elements as a generator 0, or 2-tuples of other elements.
As before we define L * R = (L,R) unless a simplification using eqn1516 is possible.

A "simplification" will happen in L * R when there are x,y such that L=(y ◇ y) and R=(x ◇ (x ◇ y)),
in which case L * R = x.

Squaring will never trigger a simplification, so for all x, x * x = (x, x).
This means we can determine if L is a square, and get y from L unambiguously.

The simplification rule is enforcing eqn1516, x = (y ◇ y) ◇ (x ◇ (x ◇ y))
and therefore ( (x ◇ (x ◇ z)) = (y ◇ (y ◇ z)) ) <-> (x=y).
So given elements R,y if we find an x such that R=(x ◇ (x ◇ y)), it is unique.

The depth of the tuple L * R (if viewed as defining a tree), will be less than the max depth of L or R if a simplification occurred. So given R and y, we can just search for an x with depth < max(depth(R), depth(L)) such that R=(x ◇ (x ◇ y)). If we find one, it is unique. If none is found, there is no smaller depth element to reduce to, and the result is just the tuple (L,R).
Isn't it possible that a simplification occurred in the definition of R?
yes, that is what the search is intended to handle.
But then can't the depth of R be less than the depth of x?

Yes, but if L * R can result in a simplification, we must be able to write R in the form x * (x * y) where y comes from L = y * y = (y, y). And we'll search for x up to max(depth(L), depth(R)). So in some cases we will search beyond the depth of R.
But isn't it possible that y is very small, x is very large, but some sequence of simplifications caused R to simplify to something smaller than x?

I think you are going down a similar path to the one I took in trying to construct something close to the free 1516 magma. I think the approach has a chance of eventually working, but is quite complex and as such I was reluctant to push for it. But since it seems to be emerging organically, perhaps I will share more of the computations that I have.

Say that (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) is a "simplification triple" if one has x⋄(y⋄z)=yx \diamond (y \diamond z) = yx⋄(y⋄z)=y. Then 1516 asserts that (Sy,x,x⋄y)(Sy, x, x \diamond y)(Sy,x,x⋄y) is a simplification triple for any x,yx,yx,y, where Sy=y⋄ySy = y \diamond ySy=y⋄y is the squaring operator. One can hope that most of the time one can write x⋄y=(x,y)x \diamond y = (x,y)x⋄y=(x,y) (and also x⋄(x⋄y)=(x,(x,y))x \diamond (x \diamond y) = (x,(x, y))x⋄(x⋄y)=(x,(x,y))), and that the simplification rules given by this case (i.e., Sy⋄(x,(x,y))=xSy \diamond (x,(x,y)) = xSy⋄(x,(x,y))=x) are close to a complete set of simplifications. This was where I was a few days ago, and I'm guessing that this is the hope right now.

But there are some complications. Firstly, there is a propagation property of simplification triples:

Lemma 1. If (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) is a simplification triple, then so is (S(y⋄z),x,y)(S(y \diamond z), x, y)(S(y⋄z),x,y).

Proof: By hypothesis, y=x⋄(y⋄z)y = x \diamond (y \diamond z)y=x⋄(y⋄z), thus S(y⋄z)⋄(x⋄y)=S(y⋄z)⋄(x⋄(x⋄(y⋄z)))=x.S(y \diamond z) \diamond (x \diamond y) = S(y \diamond z) \diamond (x \diamond (x \diamond (y \diamond z))) = x.S(y⋄z)⋄(x⋄y)=S(y⋄z)⋄(x⋄(x⋄(y⋄z)))=x. □\Box□

So in addition to the original simplification triples (Sy,x,x⋄y)(Sy,x, x \diamond y)(Sy,x,x⋄y), one also has

(S(x⋄(x⋄y)),Sy,x) (S(x \diamond (x \diamond y)), Sy, x)(S(x⋄(x⋄y)),Sy,x)

(S(Sy⋄x),S(x⋄(x⋄y)),Sy) (S(Sy \diamond x), S(x \diamond (x \diamond y)), Sy)(S(Sy⋄x),S(x⋄(x⋄y)),Sy)

(S(S(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄Sy),S(Sy⋄x),S(x⋄(x⋄y))) (S(S(x \diamond (x \diamond y)) \diamond Sy), S(Sy \diamond x), S(x \diamond (x \diamond y)))(S(S(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄Sy),S(Sy⋄x),S(x⋄(x⋄y)))

and so forth.

This still isn't so bad, one could just add all of these to the list of simplification rules, show that they don't conflict with each other, and hope that now we have a near-complete list of simplifying rules. I tried this, but another problem emerged. There are some "sporadic" simplifying rules a⋄b=ca \diamond b = ca⋄b=c that are not of the standard form x⋄(y⋄z)=yx \diamond (y \diamond z) = yx⋄(y⋄z)=y (in the sense that bbb is not expected to be of the form b=(c,d)b = (c,d)b=(c,d) for some ddd). An example is the rule SCx⋄Sx=SxSCx \diamond Sx = SxSCx⋄Sx=Sx, where CxCxCx is the cubing map Cx=Sx⋄xCx = Sx \diamond xCx=Sx⋄x (this is related to the previously observed fact that SSS and CCC commute, as well as the fact that in the constant cubing case Cx=2Cx = 2Cx=2 one has 2⋄Sx=Sx2 \diamond Sx = Sx2⋄Sx=Sx). At first I thought there were only a small number of sporadic rules (a finite number of rules parameterized by one variable xxx), but then I found more due to this lemma:

Lemma 2. If (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) and (x,y⋄z,w)(x, y \diamond z, w)(x,y⋄z,w) are simplifying triples, then we have the sporadic identity S((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄y=xS((y \diamond z) \diamond w) \diamond y = xS((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄y=x.

Proof: By hypothesis, x⋄(y⋄z)=yx \diamond (y \diamond z) = yx⋄(y⋄z)=y and x⋄((y⋄z)⋄w)=y⋄zx \diamond ((y \diamond z) \diamond w) = y \diamond zx⋄((y⋄z)⋄w)=y⋄z, thus S((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄y=S((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄(x⋄(x⋄((y⋄z)⋄w))=xS((y \diamond z) \diamond w) \diamond y = S((y \diamond z) \diamond w) \diamond (x \diamond (x \diamond ((y \diamond z) \diamond w)) = xS((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄y=S((y⋄z)⋄w)⋄(x⋄(x⋄((y⋄z)⋄w))=x. □\Box□

For instance, since we know (Sy,x,x⋄y)(Sy,x,x \diamond y)(Sy,x,x⋄y) and (Sy,x⋄(x⋄y),(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄y))(Sy, x \diamond (x \diamond y), (x \diamond (x \diamond y)) \diamond y))(Sy,x⋄(x⋄y),(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄y)) are simplifying triples, we have the sporadic identity SF(x,y)⋄x=Sy S F(x,y) \diamond x = SySF(x,y)⋄x=Sy, where F(x,y)F(x,y)F(x,y) is the word

F(x,y)=(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄((x⋄(x⋄y))⋄y). F(x,y) = (x \diamond (x \diamond y)) \diamond ((x \diamond (x \diamond y)) \diamond y).F(x,y)=(x⋄(x⋄y))⋄((x⋄(x⋄y))⋄y).

Okay, so we have to add a few sporadic identities in addition to the previous families of simplifying triple identities. Now do we have something close to a complete set of simplifying rules? Well, unfortunately sporadic identities beget further sporadic identities:

Lemma 3. If we have a sporadic identity of the form Sx⋄y=zSx \diamond y = zSx⋄y=z, then we get another sporadic identity of the form S(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄z=SxS(y \diamond (y \diamond x)) \diamond z = SxS(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄z=Sx.

Proof. S(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄z=S(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄(Sx⋄Sx⋄(y⋄(y⋄x))=Sx.S(y \diamond (y \diamond x)) \diamond z = S(y \diamond (y \diamond x)) \diamond (Sx \diamond Sx \diamond (y \diamond (y \diamond x)) = Sx.S(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄z=S(y⋄(y⋄x))⋄(Sx⋄Sx⋄(y⋄(y⋄x))=Sx. □\Box□

So for instance starting from SF(x,y)⋄y=SxSF(x,y) \diamond y = SxSF(x,y)⋄y=Sx we have

S(F(x,y)⋄(F(x,y)⋄x))⋄Sx=SF(x,y) S(F(x,y) \diamond (F(x,y) \diamond x)) \diamond Sx = SF(x,y)S(F(x,y)⋄(F(x,y)⋄x))⋄Sx=SF(x,y)

and this can be iterated further to obtain an increasingly complex sequence of sporadic identities.

So, now are we done? Regrettably, there is another propagation vector: sporadic identities also generate new simplifying triples!

Lemma 4. If we have a sporadic identity x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z, then we have a simplifying triple (Sy,x,z)(Sy, x, z)(Sy,x,z).

Proof. This is just a specialization of the previous observation that (Sy,x,x⋄y)(Sy, x, x \diamond y)(Sy,x,x⋄y) is always a simplifying triple. □\Box□

So now we have a potential feedback loop in which simplifying triples and sporadic identities beget each other in a combinatorial explosion. However, with my computations it seems that this explosion is barely averted: the "simplifying triple -> sporadic identity" vector in Lemma 2 requires two simplifying triples to create a sporadic identity, and it appears that all of the additional simplifying triples beyond the standard ones (Sy,x,x∗y)(Sy, x, x * y)(Sy,x,x∗y) do not actually generate any further sporadic identities, and so the process stops with a finite (but rather complex) collection of families of both simplifying triples and sporadic identities.

Here is part I of the complex proposal to build a nearly free 1516 magma. It requires one to guess a good ruleset of "sporadic rules" and "simplifying rules" that need to obey 12 axioms, but I am still working on a viable proposal for what that good ruleset might be. Most likely the first few iterations of the proposal won't quite close and so one will need to keep tweaking it. This is a very tedious and error-prone process to do by hand, so we may have to look into more automated options.

--

We work in the free algebra generated by a pairing operation (,)(,)(,) and two commuting unary operators S,CS,CS,C, and some set of generators (one could also work with the natural numbers with pairing (x,y)=2x3y(x,y)=2^x 3^y(x,y)=2x3y, Sx=5xSx = 5xSx=5x, and Cx=7xCx=7xCx=7x, but I don't think this actually simplifies anything). We assume that we have a collection of "sporadic rules" x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z, as well as "simplifying rules" of the form x⋄(y,z)=yx \diamond (y,z) = yx⋄(y,z)=y for some collection of "simplifying triples" (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z). This lets us define an operation ⋄\diamond⋄ on the free algebra by the following rules:

  • (Sporadic case) If x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z is a sporadic rule, then we define x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y equal to zzz.
  • (Simplifying case) If (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) is a simplifying triple, we define x⋄(y,z)x \diamond (y,z)x⋄(y,z) equal to yyy.
  • (Generic case) In all other cases, we define x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y to equal (x,y)(x,y)(x,y).

In order for this to give a magma, we need to verify two axioms:

Axiom 1. If x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z and x⋄y=z′x \diamond y = z'x⋄y=z′ are both sporadic rules, then z=z′z=z'z=z′.
Axiom 2. If (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) is a simplifying triple, then there are no sporadic rules of the form x⋄(y,z)=wx \diamond (y,z) = wx⋄(y,z)=w.

We would like to have x⋄x=Sxx \diamond x = Sxx⋄x=Sx for all xxx, so we impose

Axiom 3. For any xxx, x⋄x=Sxx \diamond x = Sxx⋄x=Sx is a sporadic rule.

Now we need to verify 1516, which is Sx⋄(y⋄(y⋄x))=ySx \diamond (y \diamond (y \diamond x)) = ySx⋄(y⋄(y⋄x))=y. Note that y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x can be sporadic, simplifying, or generic; and y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) can also be sporadic, simplifying, or generic. So there are nine cases to consider.

Case 1: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is generic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is generic. Then we need to show Sx⋄(y,(y,x))=x Sx \diamond (y, (y,x)) = xSx⋄(y,(y,x))=x and so it will suffice to have

Axiom 4. If y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x and y⋄(y,x)y \diamond (y,x)y⋄(y,x) are generic, then (Sx,y,(y,x))(Sx, y, (y,x))(Sx,y,(y,x)) is a simplifying triple.

Remark: This axiom should somehow contribute the "most frequently encountered" simplifying triples (otherwise this method is unlikely to work).

Case 2: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is simplifying; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is generic. Then we have x=(z,w)x = (z, w)x=(z,w), y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z, and y⋄zy \diamond zy⋄z generic. So we need to have

Axiom 5. If (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) is a simplifying triple and y⋄zy \diamond zy⋄z is generic, then (S(z,w),y,z)(S(z,w), y, z)(S(z,w),y,z) is a simplifying triple.

Remark: Iterating this axiom twice, we expect to see simplifying triples of the form (S(y,z),S(z,w),y)(S(y,z), S(z,w), y)(S(y,z),S(z,w),y). I am hoping we can truncate the ruleset by declaring all such triples to be simplifying triples.

Case 3: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is sporadic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is generic. Then we have some sporadic rule y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z and y⋄zy \diamond zy⋄z is generic. So it suffices to have

Axiom 6. If y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z is a sporadic rule and y⋄zy \diamond zy⋄z is generic, then (Sx,y,z)(Sx, y, z)(Sx,y,z) is a simplifying triple.

Remark: This axiom basically means that every sporadic rule also generates a simplifying triple.

Case 4: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is generic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is simplifying.

In this case y⋄(y⋄x)=yy \diamond (y \diamond x) = yy⋄(y⋄x)=y. So we need

Axiom 7. If y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is generic and (y,y,x)(y,y,x)(y,y,x) is a simplifying triple, then Sx⋄y=ySx \diamond y = ySx⋄y=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping that this axiom only activates very rarely.

Case 5: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is simplifying; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is simplifying.

We now have x=((z,w),u)x = ((z,w),u)x=((z,w),u) for some simplifying triples (y,(z,w),u)(y,(z,w),u)(y,(z,w),u) and (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w). So we need

Axiom 8. If (y,(z,w),u)(y,(z,w),u)(y,(z,w),u) and (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) are simplifying triples, then S((z,w),u)⋄z=yS((z,w),u) \diamond z = yS((z,w),u)⋄z=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping that this axiom mainly only activates when both simplifying triples arose from Axiom 4. This gives rise to the sporadic rules SF(x,y)⋄x=SySF(x,y) \diamond x = SySF(x,y)⋄x=Sy where F(x,y)=B(B(x,y),y)F(x,y) = B(B(x,y),y)F(x,y)=B(B(x,y),y) and B(x,y)=(x,(x,y))B(x,y) = (x,(x,y))B(x,y)=(x,(x,y)). Another consequence of this axiom is that if x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z is sporadic, then almost certainly we will have to have the sporadic rule SB((x,z),y)⋄x=SyS B((x,z),y) \diamond x = SySB((x,z),y)⋄x=Sy.

Case 6: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is sporadic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is simplifying.

So now y⋄x=(z,w)y \diamond x = (z,w)y⋄x=(z,w) is a sporadic rule and (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) is a simplifying triple. The axiom we need then is

Axiom 9. If y⋄x=(z,w)y \diamond x = (z,w)y⋄x=(z,w) is a sporadic rule and (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) is a simplifying triple, then Sx⋄z=ySx \diamond z = ySx⋄z=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping that this axiom activates very rarely.

Case 7: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is generic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is sporadic.

Here we have y⋄(y,x)=zy \diamond (y,x) = zy⋄(y,x)=z as a sporadic rule. So the axiom needed here is

Axiom 10. If y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is generic and y⋄(y,x)=zy \diamond (y,x) = zy⋄(y,x)=z is a sporadic rule, then Sx⋄z=ySx \diamond z = ySx⋄z=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping that this axiom only activates very rarely.

Case 8: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is simplifying; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is sporadic.

So now x=(z,w)x = (z,w)x=(z,w) for some simplifying triple (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) and there is a sporadic rule y⋄z=uy \diamond z = uy⋄z=u. So the axiom needed is

Axiom 11. If (y,z,w)(y,z,w)(y,z,w) is a simplifying triple and y⋄z=uy \diamond z = uy⋄z=u is a sporadic rule, then S(z,w)⋄u=yS(z,w) \diamond u = yS(z,w)⋄u=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping this axiom is activated primarily when the simplifying triple arose from Axiom 4, in which case it asserts that the sporadic rule Sy⋄z=uSy \diamond z = uSy⋄z=u creates the sporadic rule SB(z,y)⋄u=SySB(z,y) \diamond u = SySB(z,y)⋄u=Sy, which in turn creates the sporadic rule SB(u,B(z,y))⋄Sy=SB(z,y)SB(u,B(z,y)) \diamond Sy = SB(z,y)SB(u,B(z,y))⋄Sy=SB(z,y), where B(z,y)=(z,(z,y))B(z,y) = (z,(z,y))B(z,y)=(z,(z,y)).

Case 9: y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x is sporadic; y⋄(y⋄x)y \diamond (y \diamond x)y⋄(y⋄x) is sporadic.

So now we have two sporadic rules y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z and y⋄z=wy \diamond z = wy⋄z=w, and the axiom needed is

Axiom 12. If y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z and y⋄z=wy \diamond z = wy⋄z=w are sporadic rules, then Sx⋄w=ySx \diamond w = ySx⋄w=y is a sporadic rule.

Remark: I am hoping that this axiom activates only rarely.

One could imagine setting up an automated scheme in which one starts with a good "seed" of sporadic rules and simplifying triples, and then runs the above axioms to generate more, hoping that the process terminates without creating a contradiction (a violation of Axiom 1 or Axiom 2). I have some ideas for what the seed should be, but I am still working on it.

Here is a simplification of the approach in which we abandon the concept of a "simplifying triple" by absorbing it into the "sporadic rules", which are now a larger family of rules x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z. The magma operation is now given by just two rules:

  • (Sporadic case) If x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z is a sporadic rule, then we define x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y equal to zzz.
  • (Generic case) In all other cases, we define x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y to equal (x,y)(x,y)(x,y).

Naively, one could try to suspend all genericity hypotheses and work with the following slightly too-strong axioms:
Axiom 1 If x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z and x⋄y=z′x \diamond y = z'x⋄y=z′ are both sporadic rules, then z=z′z=z'z=z′.
Axiom 2 We have the sporadic rule x⋄x=Sxx \diamond x = Sxx⋄x=Sx.
Axiom 3 For every x,yx,yx,y, we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄(y,(y,x))=x Sx \diamond (y, (y,x)) = xSx⋄(y,(y,x))=x.
Axiom 4 If we have the sporadic rule y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z, then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄(y,z)=ySx \diamond (y,z) = ySx⋄(y,z)=y.
Axiom 5 If we have the sporadic rule y⋄(y,x)=zy \diamond (y,x) = zy⋄(y,x)=z, then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄z=ySx \diamond z = ySx⋄z=y.
Axiom 6 If we have the sporadic rules y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z and y⋄z=wy \diamond z = wy⋄z=w, then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄w=ySx \diamond w = ySx⋄w=y.

Unfortunately, the commutativity of squaring and cubing shows that these axioms are inconsistent. More precisely:

  1. From Axiom 1 and Axiom 4 we have Sx⋄(x,Sx)=xSx \diamond (x,Sx) = xSx⋄(x,Sx)=x.
  2. From 1. and Axiom 4 we have S(x,Sx)⋄(Sx,x)=SxS(x,Sx) \diamond (Sx,x) = SxS(x,Sx)⋄(Sx,x)=Sx.
  3. From Axiom 3 we have Sx⋄(Sx,(Sx,x))=SxSx \diamond (Sx, (Sx,x)) = SxSx⋄(Sx,(Sx,x))=Sx.
  4. From 3. and Axiom 5 we have S(Sx,x)⋄Sx=SxS(Sx,x) \diamond Sx = SxS(Sx,x)⋄Sx=Sx.
  5. From 4. (twice) and Axiom 6 we have S2x⋄Sx=S(Sx,x)S^2 x \diamond Sx = S(Sx,x)S2x⋄Sx=S(Sx,x).
  6. From 1., 5., and Axiom 6 we have S(Sx,S2x)⋄S(Sx,x)=S2xS(Sx, S^2 x) \diamond S(Sx,x) = S^2 xS(Sx,S2x)⋄S(Sx,x)=S2x.
  7. From 5. and Axiom 4 we have S2x⋄(S2x,S(Sx,x))=S2xS^2 x \diamond (S^2 x, S(Sx,x)) = S^2 xS2x⋄(S2x,S(Sx,x))=S2x.
  8. From 7. and Axiom 5 we have S2(Sx,x)⋄S2x=S2xS^2(Sx,x) \diamond S^2 x = S^2 xS2(Sx,x)⋄S2x=S2x.
  9. From 8. (twice) and Axiom 6 we have S3x⋄S2x=S2(Sx,x).S^3 x \diamond S^2 x = S^2(Sx,x).S3x⋄S2x=S2(Sx,x).
  10. On the other hand, from 5. we have S3x⋄S2x=S(S2x,Sx).S^3 x \diamond S^2 x = S(S^2 x, Sx).S3x⋄S2x=S(S2x,Sx). This and 9. now violate Axiom 1, since S2(Sx,x)≠S(S2x,Sx)S^2(Sx,x) \neq S(S^2 x, Sx)S2(Sx,x)=S(S2x,Sx) in the free magma.

To fix this we have to implement the cubing operator CCC, and replace any occurrence of (Sx,x)(Sx,x)(Sx,x) by CxCxCx. This requires adding the additional sporadic axiom
Axiom 2' Sx⋄x=CxSx \diamond x = CxSx⋄x=Cx
and then also reinstating as much of the genericity hypotheses to the axioms as we can. So, at a given state of the ruleset, we replace Axioms 3-5 with
Axiom 3' For every x,yx,yx,y, if we do not currently have any rule for y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x or for y⋄(y,x)y \diamond (y,x)y⋄(y,x), then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄(y,(y,x))=x Sx \diamond (y, (y,x)) = xSx⋄(y,(y,x))=x.
Axiom 4' If we have the sporadic rule y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z, but we do not currently have any rule for y⋄zy \diamond zy⋄z, then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄(y,z)=ySx \diamond (y,z) = ySx⋄(y,z)=y.
Axiom 5' If we have the sporadic rule y⋄(y,x)=zy \diamond (y,x) = zy⋄(y,x)=z, but we currently do not have any rule for y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x, then we have the sporadic rule Sx⋄z=ySx \diamond z = ySx⋄z=y.

We can then try to dynamically grow the ruleset starting from just Axiom 2 and Axiom 2' by greedily trying to verify Axioms 3', 4', 5'; the previous contradiction is now blocked from occuring. I suspect that to block a collision later on, we will also need to impose
Axiom 2'' (Sx,Cx)⋄((Sx,Cx),x)=Cx(Sx, Cx) \diamond ((Sx,Cx),x) = Cx(Sx,Cx)⋄((Sx,Cx),x)=Cx.
(This law does not appear to be forced by 1516, but its square is, so we have to include it in this ansatz, as squaring is necessarily injective here. By the way this seems to indicate that squaring is not injective in the free magma, which means that this approach will not be able to capture that free magma precisely, but it may still get close enough to it that we can still refute 255.)

It may be possible to just run a greedy algorithm on this initial ruleset and see numerically if any collisions occur. This will not terminate currently, but it might give some hope that the strategy could work, and one can then try to add a few more seed axioms (motivated by, but not forced by, 1516) to force termination in finite time.

Here is the full report from the automated search on law 1516.

My paradigm for running the search was that instead of thinking of x⋄yx\diamond yx⋄y as (when possible) the expression x∗yx\ast yx∗y in the free magma, and instead of writing it as (x,y)(x,y)(x,y), I instead treated it as a new "function" following the Kisielewicz ansatz. [This is really just a renaming procedure, but it was helpful for my own understanding.]

So, for example, x⋄x=Sxx\diamond x=Sxx⋄x=Sx is a new function, and Sx⋄x=CxSx\diamond x=CxSx⋄x=Cx is a new function, and Cx⋄x=QxCx\diamond x=QxCx⋄x=Qx is a new function, and so forth. After this point I just started calling the new functions p1,p2,…p_1,p_2,\ldotsp1​,p2​,…. Some of the other important functions that showed up are p1x:=x⋄Sxp_1x:=x\diamond Sxp1​x:=x⋄Sx, p2x=Sx⋄Cxp_2x=Sx\diamond Cxp2​x=Sx⋄Cx, p3x=Cx⋄Qxp_3x=Cx\diamond Qxp3​x=Cx⋄Qx, and finally p15x=S2x⋄(S2x⋄x)p_{15}x=S^2x\diamond(S^2x\diamond x)p15​x=S2x⋄(S2x⋄x).

Now, the 1516 law is x=(y⋄y)⋄(x⋄(x⋄y))x=(y\diamond y)\diamond (x\diamond (x\diamond y))x=(y⋄y)⋄(x⋄(x⋄y)). I thought about it in the following way. Once we know that x⋄y=p(x,y)x\diamond y=p(x,y)x⋄y=p(x,y) is defined (either as a new function or a composition of previously defined functions), then we generally want to define x⋄p(x,y)x\diamond p(x,y)x⋄p(x,y) as a brand-new function p′(x,y)p'(x,y)p′(x,y), and then we must take Sy⋄p′(x,y)=xSy\diamond p'(x,y)=xSy⋄p′(x,y)=x, which is not a new function. So each defined product generally gives rise to two new defined products, both involving the new function in some way.

Let me show how this worked in practice. Suppose we have derived the equality x⋄Sx=p1xx\diamond Sx=p_1xx⋄Sx=p1​x. From this, we want to take x⋄p1x=p4xx\diamond p_1x=p_4xx⋄p1​x=p4​x (a brand-new function), and then we must also take Sx⋄p2x=xSx\diamond p_2x=xSx⋄p2​x=x.

There were two dangers in this. First, when x⋄yx\diamond yx⋄y is defined, it might also be the case that x⋄(x⋄y)x\diamond (x\diamond y)x⋄(x⋄y) is also already (previously) defined, so we cannot adjoin a new function (i.e. we have to use the previously defined answer). This happened exactly five times (involving those five special functions above). For example, we had the equality Sx⋄p1x=xSx\diamond p_1x=xSx⋄p1​x=x. We can't define then Sx⋄xSx\diamond xSx⋄x as a new function, because we already had it equals CxCxCx.

The second danger was that when defining Sy⋄(x⋄(x⋄y))Sy\diamond (x\diamond (x\diamond y))Sy⋄(x⋄(x⋄y)) as xxx, it might also already have a different definition; so there could be collisions, where the expressions don't match.

The first collision it found was CS=SCCS=SCCS=SC. To accommodate this issue, I had to modify the composition of functions to always concentrate sequential powers of SSS and CCC together. The next collision it found was that QS=SQS=SQS=S. This causes problems with some new functions like p3p_3p3​, because then p3S=CS⋄QS=CS⋄S=QS=Sp_3S=CS\diamond QS=CS\diamond S=QS=Sp3​S=CS⋄QS=CS⋄S=QS=S. After adding the rules for these new types of collisions (essentially adding a new, third infinite family of reduction rules) there were no other collisions that the program found.

Sure! My starting point was to view the equation 1516 as a constraint LSyLx2y=xL_{Sy} L_x^2 y = xLSy​Lx2​y=x between the various left shift maps LxL_xLx​, and to first see what conditions they impose on the left shift maps La:M→ML_a: M \to MLa​:M→M for aaa in the squares SMSMSM. Here I assume that the magma operation on SMSMSM has already been defined, so the question is what LaL_aLa​ does on the non-squares, which at present are a completely unknown set. In order to fill out the multiplication table on the non-squares later, also know that I will need these LaL_aLa​ to be surjective, and for the greedy algorithm to work I would in fact like them to really surjective, with every element having infinitely many preimages, not just at least one.

From the analysis of the case when SMSMSM was finite, I extracted the following argument. Let yyy be some non-square, and let bbb be a square. We know that LbL_bLb​ is surjective, hence y=Lb2zy = L_b^2 zy=Lb2​z for some z=zb,yz = z_{b,y}z=zb,y​. Writing cb,y=Szb,yc_{b,y} = Sz_{b,y}cb,y​=Szb,y​, we obtain Lcb,yy=LSzLb2z=bL_{c_{b,y}} y = L_{Sz} L_b^2 z = bLcb,y​​y=LSz​Lb2​z=b. Thus, each non-square yyy comes with a function b↦cb,yb \mapsto c_{b,y}b↦cb,y​ from squares to squares with the property that Lcb,yy=bL_{c_{b,y}} y = bLcb,y​​y=b. This function is clearly injective. When the squares are finite, this forces the function to be surjective, and now this is a problem because this has completely determined all of the left shift maps LaL_aLa​ on squares, and forced them to also take values in the squares, which by surjectivity means that there are no non-squares! So we need infinitely many squares, and we also need the function cb,yc_{b,y}cb,y​ to omit at least one element ccc in its range.

So, every non-square yyy now should come with two important square numbers - its own square SySySy, which I denoted aaa, and an auxiliary square ccc, for which LcyL_c yLc​y is not automatically defined by the Lcb,yyL_{c_{b,y}} yLcb,y​​y rule and can be free to assign to help fulfill requirements such as the (infinite) surjectivity of LcL_cLc​. For greedy algorithm purposes it would be nice to have a lot of yyy s for each possible choice of pair (a,c)(a,c)(a,c).
